<p><strong>In this edition </strong>of<em> <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks">Author Talks</a></em>, McKinsey Global Publishings Raju Narisetti chats with Marina Nitze, former chief technology officer for the US Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), about her new book, <em>Hack Your Bureaucracy: Get Things Done No Matter What Your Role on Any Team</em> (Hachette Go, September 2022), cowritten by Nick Sinai, a senior adviser at Insight Partners. The first step to effectively navigating bureaucracy is accepting that it exists in almost every system, Nitze sayseven at a grocery co-op. Rather than try to avoid the unavoidable, Nitze has spent her career tackling bureaucratic slowdowns head-on. Now, shes sharing the strategies that worked at the White House and beyond. An edited version of the conversation follows.</p>
<p><strong>Can you explain your tips for hacking bureaucracy, starting with, 1.   Be the queen on the chessboard?</strong></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-o-sm-left-span Image_mck-c-image__fhx5v"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Image_mck-c-image__img-container__JusDB"><img alt="Marina Nitze image" src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/mckinsey%20books/author%20talks%20how%20to%20make%20bureaucracy%20work%20for%20you/marina%20martin_credit%20johnny%20shryock_1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mw=767&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-9 mdc-u-mt-3 Image_mck-c-image__description__nsDz3"><div>Marina Nitze</div></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">Marina Nitze image</div></div>
<p>My coauthor, Nick Sinai, and I wrote <em>Hack Your Bureaucracy</em>, which has over 50 tactics for getting things done in any bureaucracy, no matter what your role on any team. When youre playing chess, the queen can go forward, backward, and diagonal, unlike the other pieces. This is where I encourage you, wherever you are in a bureaucracyeven if youre outside itto try to follow the path from end to end across the experience that youre trying to fix. I have a funny story about this in child welfare.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>I was watching a state welfare officer process foster-parent applications. The woman was filling out a carbon copy triplicate formthe ones where you press really hard with your pen and go through to the differently colored pagesto request the applicants driving record. I asked, Why are you filling out this old form? And she said, Its because the people at the DMV [Department of Motor Vehicles] live in the 19th century. Theyre still using this old paper process.</p>
<p>Because Im the queen on the chessboard, I did something that that woman couldnt do. I went over to the DMV, and I asked how they process those kinds of forms. To my surprise, the woman working at the DMV pulled up an electronic request system and showed me how they process requests that way. I said to her, Wait a minute. Where does the carbon copy paper fit in? And she said, Oh, you must have been at child welfare. They live in the 19th century.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>By figuring out that these two parts of the process werent connecting, we were able to remove a cumbersome part of the process, with absolutely no opposition, almost overnight. Thats why I encourage you to be the queen on the chessboard.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>By figuring out that these two parts of the process werent connecting, we were able to remove a cumbersome part of the process, with absolutely no opposition, almost overnight. Thats why I encourage you to be the queen on the chessboard  and go everywhere that you may need to go to understand how a process really works.</p>
<p><strong>2. Find your Trojan horse</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>The Trojan horse is about looking for the area of the process youre trying to change that has the least opposition and defensive antibodies. For example, in <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-states-can-improve-well-being-for-all-children-from-birth-to-age-five">child welfare</a>, people tend to focus a lot on the chronological start of a process, such as the child-abuse hotline, but thats the most dangerous part of the process to changeits where there are a lot of vested interests, so its really scary to make change. Its better to look at another part of the process, like foster-parent applications, where theres a lot of room for improving efficiencies without facing oppositional forces.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>If you can find that Trojan horse area of the processwhere you can get people to buy into change, however smallyou can start earning the political capital and trust that you need, plus the understanding of how the organization works.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>If you can find that Trojan horse area of the processwhere you can get people to buy into change, however smallyou can start earning the political capital and trust that you need, plus the understanding of how the organization works  and its risk and incentive frameworks. Then you can tackle the next most challenging part of the puzzle.</p>
<p><strong>3. Ask people to tell you about a mystery</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>I love this tactic when Im shadowing people doing their work. I ask them if they can tell me a mystery, and youd be surprisedusually, people have one. It may be that they dont know where a certain form goes. It may be that they dont know why we ask a certain question.</p>
<p>If you ask people to tell you a mystery while youre shadowing their job, and then find the answer to that mystery, and you go back and tell them, not only have you probably made a friend for life, but often itll uncover an inefficiency or an area for improvement that you wouldnt have found otherwise.</p>
<p><strong>4. <strong></strong>Create (but dont share) the stakeholder map<strong></strong></strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>A stakeholder map can be your number-one tool in bureaucracy hacking, but the most effective <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/one-ceos-journey-to-becoming-a-business-builder">stakeholder</a> map has enough detail on it that you probably want to keep it to yourself and not share it. We think of bureaucracies as places where people spend tens of years, which may be true, but even in big government bureaucracies where people tend to have life appointments, they move around. They have different friends. Theyll move from departments or from agencies.</p>
<p>What you want to do is forget the hierarchy on the formal org chart and look at how people actually interact. Who has power over the budget? Who has power over the bosss calendar? Who used to work together? And then who is willing to work with you? Thats a totally different question.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>More on the state of bureaucracy</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>You actually have a benign view of bureaucracywhy?</strong></p>
<p>In the course of writing our book, we tried to find an example of something that was not a bureaucracywe even went to a UC Berkeley grocery co-op. We just couldnt find one. At the end of the day, we all live inside a bureaucracy.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Im always reminded of the childrens rhyme from <em>Were Going on a Bear Hunt: </em>Cant go over it. Cant go under it. Cant go around it. Got to go through it. I think wed all be better off if we acknowledged we were inside bureaucracies, and instead of complaining about it, we learned how to operate within them.</p>
<p>Most bureaucratic problems ultimately have human solutions. At the end of the day, most organizations are designed for how they work internallytheyre siloed, and theyre not designed around the end user that theyre serving. There continues to be an incredible wealth of opportunity and change in bureaucracies when you can highlight how that end user is being affected, whether thats a customer or a public citizen.</p>
<p><strong>Why do you say bureaucracies fall in love with details and entirely miss the destination?</strong></p>
<p>Its very often the case that bureaucracies are on ten-year plans or are trying to get plans exactly right. In the course of it, they can entirely miss the destination of what theyre trying to do. We saw this a lot at the US Veterans Administration.</p>
<p>At the end of the day, we had to realign things around, What is the goal that were trying to accomplish? And how are we measuring if were getting there?</p>
<p>If youre listening to this and you are currently working on a five-year plan or a ten-year plan, Id encourage you to stop and start trying to find one small thing you can do right now that will measure whether or not you can meaningfully change the experience of the person that youre trying to serve.</p>
<p><strong>How is the US child welfare system biased against poor families?</strong></p>
<p>Child welfare is definitely biased against poor families. There are so many instances where a mom whos struggling to make ends meet needs to leave her kids home alone so that she can work her job. For some reason, somebody finds out that the kids are home alone.</p>
<p>We remove the children, we place them with strangers in foster care, and then we give the foster parents money for day care. What if we gave Mom money for day care up front? How much intergenerational trauma would we prevent that way?</p>
<p>Theres an increasing spotlight on the fact that 60 percent of kids are in foster care for neglect, but neglect is often a synonym for poverty. If you look at foster-parent licensing rules for grandparents or other family, oftentimes, there are really unrealistic expectations, including needing recycling services, certain appliances, and other things that create an unfair disadvantage for some families. We need to do a much better job as a country of preserving families and keeping them together, instead of looking at removing children as a first step.</p>
<p><strong>What is the state of our bureaucratic union?</strong></p>
<p>Governments are getting a lot better, but theres still a lot of room for improvement. One thing we hope to get across in the book is that wherever you are, whether youre in a government or being served by a government, there are real changes that you can make.</p>
<p>One trend that governments are starting to pick up that I think will deliver outsized returns is defining metrics up front that reflect the end users experience. People dont want a report on unemployment claim backlog numbers a year later; they want that in real time. You want to be measuring contact center resolution rates in governments, thinking about customer service and experience, and making sure that people are getting the services they need and deserve in the way that they want.</p>
<p>For example, many people probably want self-service these days, and governments are building out that capacity, but self-service should still allow space for existing employees to provide manual servicein person or via phoneto the people who cant or dont want to use self-service. Being able to measure that kind of elastic capacity is a really important skill across all governments. They can all make big strides on this in the coming years.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Some of my greatest allies when I was the chief technology officer of the US Veterans Affairs were the security guards. They were interested, and they had a bit of time on their hands. One time we had a big crunch to meet a deadline, so we trained security guards in how to code HTML, and they spent hours every day helping us move content from one website to another so we could save a few million dollars by turning the old website off.</p>
<p>Those security guards have all since left and gotten careers in IT. You never know where power may lie. When you lay out what peoples risks are, what their incentives are, what theyre interested in, and what their resources are, you realize you have a lot more of a team than you may have first realized.</p>
<p><strong>5. Dont use the word just</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>Dont use the word just. I actually have a text expander shortcut on my computer, so if I type the word just, it will delete it automatically for me. Theres no just in a bureaucracy. Nothing is as simple as it may seem. When you go through your bureaucracy and try to figure out the way to solve a problem, be really careful of saying to somebody, We <em>just</em> need to do this or that to solve it. Before you say that, you should dig into the details to make sure you understand whats going on.</p>
<p><strong>6. Dont only aim for cultural change</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>Everyone aims for <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/a-single-approach-to-culture-transformation-may-not-fit-all">culture change</a> in bureaucracies. The way you get culture change is through delivering and being that change that you want to see. Ive never seen someone change a culture through PowerPoint slides, meetings, and mottoes. What changes the culture is acting differently and making incentives so that other people want to act the way that youre acting. If you want to change culture, delivery is the strategy.</p>
<p><strong>7. Go second</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Bureaucracies are designed not to change on a dime. We can complain about that, or we can acknowledge it and move accordingly.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Bureaucracies are designed not to change on a dime. We can complain about that, or we can acknowledge it and move accordingly.  One thing that bureaucracies tend not to like to do is to go first. What you want to do is make it feel like theyre going second. Maybe that means theres a comparable company or nonprofit that has done this first.</p>
<p>When I was in the government, it certainly helped when the <a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/funding-of-emerging-technology-areas-pursued-by-nontraditional-companies">Department of Defense</a> had already done something, and we, as the VA, got to go second. The more you can set it up this wayyoure not going first, youre going secondthe safer it will feel for people to do that thing. It almost creates some positive peer pressure.</p>
<p><strong>8. Run the Sinatra test</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>The Sinatra test is the idea that <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/twelve-insights-for-an-inclusive-economic-recovery-for-new-york-city">if you can make it in New York</a>, you can make it anywhere. When Nick and I were writing this book, we really wanted to share stories about places where not everybody works, like the White House and the federal government. This test is to say that if it worked in the White House, or at the VA, or in the Department of Defense, it also will work in your, perhaps, smaller company, or your local nonprofit, or your homeowners association.</p>
<p><strong>9. Dont be a tourist</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>Theres a great story in the book about Nick getting kicked out of the White House Science Fair. It accompanies our tactic to not be a tourist. Its really tempting sometimesespecially when theres a lot of attention around an event or an initiativeto want to be a part of it, but you have to have skin in the game. You have to show up, do the work, and sign up to do the hard stuff if you want to be part of the recognition of it.</p>
<p><strong>10. Go where you are rare</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>If you want to be an effective bureaucracy hacker, it helps to go where youre rare. <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/tech-talent-tectonics-ten-new-realities-for-finding-keeping-and-developing-talent">If youre a technologist</a>, go into a team that has very few technologists. If youre a lawyer, maybe you can embed with a tech team that doesnt have a legal point of view. Thats where youre going to have an outsize impact based on your skill set, whatever your skill set is.</p>
<p><strong>11. Flow people out</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>One tactic that people dont think about very often is the idea of flowing people out of your organization, just as you want to flow people in and recruit them. Nick talks a lot about some amazing examples he has where people are flowed out of federal government agencies: they work in the commercial sector for a bit, and then they go back in.</p>
<p>This can be a really great way to build your overall team and your capacity. It may feel like youre losing people for a whileand you may risk losing some people for goodbut ultimately, people will see they have more career options. Its a great way for people to grow a skill set that you may need internally, in a way thats more efficient than trying to train these skills off of three-ring binders.</p>
<p><strong>12. Dont try to make the bureaucracy care</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>One mistake I see people make constantly when theyre trying to change a bureaucracy is that they try to make the bureaucracy care with emotions. Bureaucracies dont have feelings, they have frameworks. You have to find out what forms you need to fill out and what rules you need to follow to make your change happen and do it.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Bureaucracies dont have feelings, they have frameworks. You have to find out what forms you need to fill out and what rules you need to follow to make your change happen and do it.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>One example that comes up a lot if youre trying to get a technology tool approved is the CIA triad, which is <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/strengthening-the-it-security-posture-in-corporates-and-industrials">confidentiality, integrity, and availability</a>. Nowhere on that triangle is it asking, How many veterans will die if you dont get this form on the internet? or, How many foster kids will be homeless if you dont get this spreadsheet tool in use? You can complain about that and try to appeal to peoples emotions, but what really works is to fill out the form as its being requested and try not to bring emotions into the mix.</p>
<p><strong>13. Question watercooler rules</strong></p>
<!-- -->
<p>A watercooler rule is when somebody tells you something like, It has to be printed on blue paper, or, You have to fill out this form, or, You have to get Marys sign-off. Sometimes these are true, but sometimes its just the way that things have always been done, and no one has questioned it before.</p>
<p>We encourage you to use tactics like the five whys, which is from the Toyota Production System, to get to the root of, Where does it say the rule in writing? In many cases, youll be pleasantly surprised to realize that it doesnt say this rule anywhere at all, which gives you a lot more flexibility. There are times when the rule is written down, but the original source document is more flexible than people have come to interpret it over time.</p>
<!-- -->

make bureaucracy work for you","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"c3838734-5da7-487a-afbe-125e80b1a5bc","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Author Talks: How to make bureaucracy work for you"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Hack Your Bureaucracy | Marina Nitze | McKinsey Author Talks"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Marina Nitze shares 13 tactics for successfully ushering change through any bureaucracy, from the DMV to your local not-for-profit organization."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-10-07T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn this edition \u003c/strong\u003eof\u003cem\u003e \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey Global Publishing\u0026rsquo;s Raju Narisetti chats with Marina Nitze, former chief technology officer for the US Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), about her new book, \u003cem\u003eHack Your Bureaucracy: Get Things Done No Matter What Your Role on Any Team\u003c/em\u003e (Hachette Go, September 2022), cowritten by Nick Sinai, a senior adviser at Insight Partners. The first step to effectively navigating bureaucracy is accepting that it exists in almost every system, Nitze says\u0026mdash;even at a grocery co-op. Rather than try to avoid the unavoidable, Nitze has spent her career tackling bureaucratic slowdowns head-on. Now, she\u0026rsquo;s sharing the strategies that worked at the White House and beyond. An edited version of the conversation follows.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCan you explain your tips for hacking bureaucracy, starting with, \u0026lsquo;1.   Be the queen on the chessboard\u0026rsquo;?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[image 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMy coauthor, Nick Sinai, and I wrote \u003cem\u003eHack Your Bureaucracy\u003c/em\u003e, which has over 50 tactics for getting things done in any bureaucracy, no matter what your role on any team. When you\u0026rsquo;re playing chess, the queen can go forward, backward, and diagonal, unlike the other pieces. This is where I encourage you, wherever you are in a bureaucracy\u0026mdash;even if you\u0026rsquo;re outside it\u0026mdash;to try to follow the path from end to end across the experience that you\u0026rsquo;re trying to fix. I have a funny story about this in child welfare.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eI was watching a state welfare officer process foster-parent applications. The woman was filling out a carbon copy triplicate form\u0026mdash;the ones where you press really hard with your pen and go through to the differently colored pages\u0026mdash;to request the applicant\u0026rsquo;s driving record. I asked, \u0026ldquo;Why are you filling out this old form?\u0026rdquo; And she said, \u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s because the people at the DMV [Department of Motor Vehicles] live in the 19th century. They\u0026rsquo;re still using this old paper process.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause I\u0026rsquo;m the queen on the chessboard, I did something that that woman couldn\u0026rsquo;t do. I went over to the DMV, and I asked how they process those kinds of forms. To my surprise, the woman working at the DMV pulled up an electronic request system and showed me how they process requests that way. I said to her, \u0026ldquo;Wait a minute. Where does the carbon copy paper fit in?\u0026rdquo; And she said, \u0026ldquo;Oh, you must have been at child welfare. They live in the 19th century.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eBy figuring out that these two parts of the process weren\u0026rsquo;t connecting, we were able to remove a cumbersome part of the process, with absolutely no opposition, almost overnight. That\u0026rsquo;s why I encourage you to be the queen on the chessboard  and go everywhere that you may need to go to understand how a process really works.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. \u0026lsquo;Find your Trojan horse\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe Trojan horse is about looking for the area of the process you\u0026rsquo;re trying to change that has the least opposition and defensive antibodies. For example, in \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-states-can-improve-well-being-for-all-children-from-birth-to-age-five\"\u003echild welfare\u003c/a\u003e, people tend to focus a lot on the chronological start of a process, such as the child-abuse hotline, but that\u0026rsquo;s the most dangerous part of the process to change\u0026mdash;it\u0026rsquo;s where there are a lot of vested interests, so it\u0026rsquo;s really scary to make change. It\u0026rsquo;s better to look at another part of the process, like foster-parent applications, where there\u0026rsquo;s a lot of room for improving efficiencies without facing oppositional forces.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eIf you can find that Trojan horse area of the process\u0026mdash;where you can get people to buy into change, however small\u0026mdash;you can start earning the political capital and trust that you need, plus the understanding of how the organization works  and its risk and incentive frameworks. Then you can tackle the next most challenging part of the puzzle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e3. \u0026lsquo;Ask people to tell you about a mystery\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eI love this tactic when I\u0026rsquo;m shadowing people doing their work. I ask them if they can tell me a mystery, and you\u0026rsquo;d be surprised\u0026mdash;usually, people have one. It may be that they don\u0026rsquo;t know where a certain form goes. It may be that they don\u0026rsquo;t know why we ask a certain question.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you ask people to tell you a mystery while you\u0026rsquo;re shadowing their job, and then find the answer to that mystery, and you go back and tell them, not only have you probably made a friend for life, but often it\u0026rsquo;ll uncover an inefficiency or an area for improvement that you wouldn\u0026rsquo;t have found otherwise.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e4. \u003cstrong\u003e\u0026lsquo;\u003c/strong\u003eCreate (but don\u0026rsquo;t share) the stakeholder map\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eA stakeholder map can be your number-one tool in bureaucracy hacking, but the most effective \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/one-ceos-journey-to-becoming-a-business-builder\"\u003estakeholder\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;map has enough detail on it that you probably want to keep it to yourself and not share it. We think of bureaucracies as places where people spend tens of years, which may be true, but even in big government bureaucracies where people tend to have life appointments, they move around. They have different friends. They\u0026rsquo;ll move from departments or from agencies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat you want to do is forget the hierarchy on the formal org chart and look at how people actually interact. Who has power over the budget? Who has power over the boss\u0026rsquo;s calendar? Who used to work together? And then who is willing to work with you? That\u0026rsquo;s a totally different question.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eSome of my greatest allies when I was the chief technology officer of the US Veterans Affairs were the security guards. They were interested, and they had a bit of time on their hands. One time we had a big crunch to meet a deadline, so we trained security guards in how to code HTML, and they spent hours every day helping us move content from one website to another so we could save a few million dollars by turning the old website off.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThose security guards have all since left and gotten careers in IT. You never know where power may lie. When you lay out what people\u0026rsquo;s risks are, what their incentives are, what they\u0026rsquo;re interested in, and what their resources are, you realize you have a lot more of a team than you may have first realized.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e5. \u0026lsquo;Don\u0026rsquo;t use the word \u0026ldquo;just\u0026rdquo;\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eDon\u0026rsquo;t use the word \u0026ldquo;just.\u0026rdquo; I actually have a text expander shortcut on my computer, so if I type the word \u0026ldquo;just,\u0026rdquo; it will delete it automatically for me. There\u0026rsquo;s no \u0026ldquo;just\u0026rdquo; in a bureaucracy. Nothing is as simple as it may seem. When you go through your bureaucracy and try to figure out the way to solve a problem, be really careful of saying to somebody, \u0026ldquo;We \u003cem\u003ejust\u003c/em\u003e need to do this or that to solve it.\u0026rdquo; Before you say that, you should dig into the details to make sure you understand what\u0026rsquo;s going on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e6. \u0026lsquo;Don\u0026rsquo;t only aim for cultural change\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eEveryone aims for \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/a-single-approach-to-culture-transformation-may-not-fit-all\"\u003eculture change\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in bureaucracies. The way you get culture change is through delivering and being that change that you want to see. I\u0026rsquo;ve never seen someone change a culture through PowerPoint slides, meetings, and mottoes. What changes the culture is acting differently and making incentives so that other people want to act the way that you\u0026rsquo;re acting. If you want to change culture, delivery is the strategy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e7. \u0026lsquo;Go second\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 7]]\n[[pullquote 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eBureaucracies are designed not to change on a dime. We can complain about that, or we can acknowledge it and move accordingly.  One thing that bureaucracies tend not to like to do is to go first. What you want to do is make it feel like they\u0026rsquo;re going second. Maybe that means there\u0026rsquo;s a comparable company or nonprofit that has done this first.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen I was in the government, it certainly helped when the \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/funding-of-emerging-technology-areas-pursued-by-nontraditional-companies\"\u003eDepartment of Defense\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;had already done something, and we, as the VA, got to go second. The more you can set it up this way\u0026mdash;you\u0026rsquo;re not going first, you\u0026rsquo;re going second\u0026mdash;the safer it will feel for people to do that thing. It almost creates some positive peer pressure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e8. \u0026lsquo;Run the Sinatra test\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 8]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe Sinatra test is the idea that \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/twelve-insights-for-an-inclusive-economic-recovery-for-new-york-city\"\u003eif you can make it in New York\u003c/a\u003e, you can make it anywhere. When Nick and I were writing this book, we really wanted to share stories about places where not everybody works, like the White House and the federal government. This test is to say that if it worked in the White House, or at the VA, or in the Department of Defense, it also will work in your, perhaps, smaller company, or your local nonprofit, or your homeowners\u0026rsquo; association.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e9. \u0026lsquo;Don\u0026rsquo;t be a tourist\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 9]]\n\u003cp\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s a great story in the book about Nick getting kicked out of the White House Science Fair. It accompanies our tactic to not be a tourist. It\u0026rsquo;s really tempting sometimes\u0026mdash;especially when there\u0026rsquo;s a lot of attention around an event or an initiative\u0026mdash;to want to be a part of it, but you have to have skin in the game. You have to show up, do the work, and sign up to do the hard stuff if you want to be part of the recognition of it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e10. \u0026lsquo;Go where you are rare\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 10]]\n\u003cp\u003eIf you want to be an effective bureaucracy hacker, it helps to go where you\u0026rsquo;re rare. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/tech-talent-tectonics-ten-new-realities-for-finding-keeping-and-developing-talent\"\u003eIf you\u0026rsquo;re a technologist\u003c/a\u003e, go into a team that has very few technologists. If you\u0026rsquo;re a lawyer, maybe you can embed with a tech team that doesn\u0026rsquo;t have a legal point of view. That\u0026rsquo;s where you\u0026rsquo;re going to have an outsize impact based on your skill set, whatever your skill set is.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e11. \u0026lsquo;Flow people out\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 11]]\n\u003cp\u003eOne tactic that people don\u0026rsquo;t think about very often is the idea of flowing people out of your organization, just as you want to flow people in and recruit them. Nick talks a lot about some amazing examples he has where people are flowed out of federal government agencies: they work in the commercial sector for a bit, and then they go back in.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis can be a really great way to build your overall team and your capacity. It may feel like you\u0026rsquo;re losing people for a while\u0026mdash;and you may risk losing some people for good\u0026mdash;but ultimately, people will see they have more career options. It\u0026rsquo;s a great way for people to grow a skill set that you may need internally, in a way that\u0026rsquo;s more efficient than trying to train these skills off of three-ring binders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e12. \u0026lsquo;Don\u0026rsquo;t try to make the bureaucracy care\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 12]]\n\u003cp\u003eOne mistake I see people make constantly when they\u0026rsquo;re trying to change a bureaucracy is that they try to make the bureaucracy care with emotions. Bureaucracies don\u0026rsquo;t have feelings, they have frameworks. You have to find out what forms you need to fill out and what rules you need to follow to make your change happen and do it.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eOne example that comes up a lot if you\u0026rsquo;re trying to get a technology tool approved is the CIA triad, which is \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/strengthening-the-it-security-posture-in-corporates-and-industrials\"\u003econfidentiality, integrity, and availability\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026rdquo; Nowhere on that triangle is it asking, \u0026ldquo;How many veterans will die if you don\u0026rsquo;t get this form on the internet?\u0026rdquo; or, \u0026ldquo;How many foster kids will be homeless if you don\u0026rsquo;t get this spreadsheet tool in use?\u0026rdquo; You can complain about that and try to appeal to people\u0026rsquo;s emotions, but what really works is to fill out the form as it\u0026rsquo;s being requested and try not to bring emotions into the mix.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e13. \u0026lsquo;Question watercooler rules\u0026rsquo;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 13]]\n\u003cp\u003eA watercooler rule is when somebody tells you something like, \u0026ldquo;It has to be printed on blue paper,\u0026rdquo; or, \u0026ldquo;You have to fill out this form,\u0026rdquo; or, \u0026ldquo;You have to get Mary\u0026rsquo;s sign-off.\u0026rdquo; Sometimes these are true, but sometimes it\u0026rsquo;s just the way that things have always been done, and no one has questioned it before.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe encourage you to use tactics like the \u0026ldquo;five whys,\u0026rdquo; which is from the Toyota Production System, to get to the root of, \u0026ldquo;Where does it say the rule in writing?\u0026rdquo; In many cases, you\u0026rsquo;ll be pleasantly surprised to realize that it doesn\u0026rsquo;t say this rule anywhere at all, which gives you a lot more flexibility. We just couldn\u0026rsquo;t find one. At the end of the day, we all live inside a bureaucracy.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[video 14]]\n\u003cp\u003eI\u0026rsquo;m always reminded of the children\u0026rsquo;s rhyme from \u003cem\u003eWe\u0026rsquo;re Going on a Bear Hunt: \u003c/em\u003e\u0026ldquo;Can\u0026rsquo;t go over it. Can\u0026rsquo;t go under it. Can\u0026rsquo;t go around it. Got to go through it.\u0026rdquo; I think we\u0026rsquo;d all be better off if we acknowledged we were inside bureaucracies, and instead of complaining about it, we learned how to operate within them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost bureaucratic problems ultimately have human solutions. At the end of the day, most organizations are designed for how they work internally\u0026mdash;they\u0026rsquo;re siloed, and they\u0026rsquo;re not designed around the end user that they\u0026rsquo;re serving. There continues to be an incredible wealth of opportunity and change in bureaucracies when you can highlight how that end user is being affected, whether that\u0026rsquo;s a customer or a public citizen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy do you say bureaucracies fall in love with details and entirely miss the destination?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s very often the case that bureaucracies are on ten-year plans or are trying to get plans exactly right. In the course of it, they can entirely miss the destination of what they\u0026rsquo;re trying to do. We saw this a lot at the US Veterans Administration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the end of the day, we had to realign things around, \u0026ldquo;What is the goal that we\u0026rsquo;re trying to accomplish? And how are we measuring if we\u0026rsquo;re getting there?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you\u0026rsquo;re listening to this and you are currently working on a five-year plan or a ten-year plan, I\u0026rsquo;d encourage you to stop and start trying to find one small thing you can do right now that will measure whether or not you can meaningfully change the experience of the person that you\u0026rsquo;re trying to serve.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow is the US child welfare system biased against poor families?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChild welfare is definitely biased against poor families. There are so many instances where a mom who\u0026rsquo;s struggling to make ends meet needs to leave her kids home alone so that she can work her job. For some reason, somebody finds out that the kids are home alone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe remove the children, we place them with strangers in foster care, and then we give the foster parents money for day care. What if we gave Mom money for day care up front? How much intergenerational trauma would we prevent that way?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s an increasing spotlight on the fact that 60 percent of kids are in foster care for neglect, but neglect is often a synonym for poverty. If you look at foster-parent licensing rules for grandparents or other family, oftentimes, there are really unrealistic expectations, including needing recycling services, certain appliances, and other things that create an unfair disadvantage for some families. We need to do a much better job as a country of preserving families and keeping them together, instead of looking at removing children as a first step.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is the state of our bureaucratic union?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments are getting a lot better, but there\u0026rsquo;s still a lot of room for improvement. One thing we hope to get across in the book is that wherever you are, whether you\u0026rsquo;re in a government or being served by a government, there are real changes that you can make.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne trend that governments are starting to pick up that I think will deliver outsized returns is defining metrics up front that reflect the end user\u0026rsquo;s experience. People don\u0026rsquo;t want a report on unemployment claim backlog numbers a year later; they want that in real time. You want to be measuring contact center resolution rates in governments, thinking about customer service and experience, and making sure that people are getting the services they need and deserve in the way that they want.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, many people probably want self-service these days, and governments are building out that capacity, but self-service should still allow space for existing employees to provide manual service\u0026mdash;in person or via phone\u0026mdash;to the people who can\u0026rsquo;t or don\u0026rsquo;t want to use self-service. Being able to measure that kind of elastic capacity is a really important skill across all governments. They can all make big strides on this in the coming years.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"More on the state of
